calculation

Show that there is no function fff that is holomorphic near 0∈C0 \in \C0∈C and satisfies

f(1n2)=n2−1n5f\p{\frac{1}{n^2}} = \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^5}f(n21​)=n5n2−1​

for all large n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.
Solution.

Suppose fff is holomorphic, and write

f(z)=∑n=0∞anznf\p{z} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n z^nf(z)=n=0∑∞​an​zn

in some small neighborhood of 000. Then

f′(0)=lim⁡n→∞f(1n2)−f(0)1/n2=n2−1−n5f(0)n3=1n−1n3−n2f(0).f'\p{0} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f\p{\frac{1}{n^2}} - f\p{0}}{1/n^2} = \frac{n^2 - 1 - n^5f\p{0}}{n^3} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n^3} - n^2f\p{0}.f′(0)=n→∞lim​1/n2f(n21​)−f(0)​=n3n2−1−n5f(0)​=n1​−n31​−n2f(0).

If f(0)≠0f\p{0} \neq 0f(0)=0, then this sequence is unbounded, which is impossible, so we require f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0. This also implies that f′(0)=0f'\p{0} = 0f′(0)=0, and so

f(z)=a2z2+z3∑n=3∞anzn−3  ⟹  n2−1n5=a2n4+1n6∑k=3∞akn2(k−3)  ⟹  n2−1n=a2+1n2∑k=3∞akn2(k−3).\begin{aligned} f\p{z} = a_2z^2 + z^3\sum_{n=3}^\infty a_n z^{n-3} &\implies \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^5} = \frac{a_2}{n^4} + \frac{1}{n^6}\sum_{k=3}^\infty \frac{a_k}{n^{2\p{k-3}}} \\ &\implies \frac{n^2 - 1}{n} = a_2 + \frac{1}{n^2} \sum_{k=3}^\infty \frac{a_k}{n^{2\p{k-3}}}. \end{aligned}f(z)=a2​z2+z3n=3∑∞​an​zn−3​⟹n5n2−1​=n4a2​​+n61​k=3∑∞​n2(k−3)ak​​⟹nn2−1​=a2​+n21​k=3∑∞​n2(k−3)ak​​.​

But sending n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, we see that a2=∞a_2 = \inftya2​=∞, which is impossible. Thus, no function fff could have existed to begin with.
